text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Finnish newspapers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT

- The Bank of Finland allowed the markka to firm sharply against the German mark on Monday, which the market interpreted as a surrender or a statement that there was no need the keep the markka in a 2.25 percent fluctuation band.
- Finnish school children are the first in the Nordic countries to have their own internet newspaper. It includes the most important daily news and a weekly information package.
- Vantaa based Kalaliike V. Hukkanen withdrew hundreds of kilogrammes of vacuum-packed whitefish due to German food poisoning case last week.
- Workers at Karhula glass plant rejected job-sharing scheme which would have introduced three six hour shifts and could have saved up to 40 jobs for some time.
- Espoo city council decides to participate in construction of planned multipurpose ice-hockey stadium.
- Industry says has been pleased with export promotion during President Martti Ahtisaari's visits abroad.
KAUPPALEHTI

- Brewer Sinebrychhoff, part of family-owned Rettig, and insurer Sampo soon to start construction of 55,000 square metres at Sinebrychoff's old brewery site in central Helsinki. Cost estimate is 500 million markka.
- Rautakirja says not interested in buying parts of Tuko from Kesko.
- Finland's technology businesses will grow to a 100 billion markka cluster by the year 2000, experts estimate.

- Finland and the other Nordic countries are tax paradises for corporations, German study says. Finland, Sweden and Norway have corporate tax rates of 28 percent compared to 65 percent in West Germany and 57 percent in East Germany.
DEMARI
- Member of the European parliament Kirsi Piha says there is no need for Finnish governments to have ministers for European affairs.
AAMULEHTI
- A crane marked in Finland has for the first time ever been found in the Sahara desert, giving new information on the birds' migration routes.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Small shop keepers oppose more liberal opening hours.
- EU rules may force Finnish dairy products manufacturer Valio to change its 17-year-old Voimarine brand name although the product is a mix of 80 percent of butter and 20 percent of margarine.
